security_audit.summary: This skill provides documentation and evaluation tools for building MCP servers. It includes Python scripts for running evaluations against MCP servers using Claude API. The scripts can spawn subprocesses for local stdio transport and make API calls to Anthropic for evaluation. All capabilities are appropriate for the stated purpose of MCP server development guidance.

medium_findings.title: Subprocess execution for MCP server testing
medium_findings.description: The evaluation harness can launch MCP servers as subprocesses via stdio transport. While legitimate for testing purposes, subprocess execution carries inherent risk. Code: `StdioServerParameters(command=self.command, args=self.args, env=self.env)` at connections.py:83-85. An attacker could potentially exploit this if they controlled the command arguments passed to the evaluation script.

medium_findings.title: Anthropic API calls for evaluation
medium_findings.description: The evaluation script calls Anthropic API to test MCP servers. Code: `client = Anthropic()` at evaluation.py:228 and `client.messages.create()` at evaluation.py:97-103. This is necessary for evaluation but requires API credentials. Users should be aware their evaluation queries are sent to Anthropic.

content.value_statement: Creating MCP servers requires understanding protocol specifications, tool design patterns, and evaluation techniques. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for building high-quality MCP servers in Python and TypeScript with working code examples and testing tools.
actual_capabilities: Follow a 4-phase process for MCP server development
Implement tools using Python FastMCP or TypeScript MCP SDK
Apply best practices for tool naming, pagination, and error handling
Create comprehensive evaluations to test MCP server effectiveness
Use multiple transport options (stdio, HTTP, SSE) for different deployment scenarios
Validate inputs with Pydantic models (Python) or Zod schemas (TypeScript)
limitations: This is a guide skill - it does not execute code or make actual API calls
Users must have Python or Node.js development experience
Evaluation script requires an Anthropic API key for testing
Does not provide pre-built MCP servers for specific services

prompt_templates.title: Get Started
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me through building my first MCP server. What are the four main phases of development and what should I focus on in each phase?

prompt_templates.title: Python Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Python MCP server for a REST API using FastMCP. Show me the project structure, tool registration pattern, and how to validate inputs with Pydantic models.

prompt_templates.title: TypeScript Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a complete TypeScript MCP server using the MCP SDK. Include proper Zod schema validation, error handling, and explain how to structure a multi-file project.

prompt_templates.title: Create Evaluations
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to create 10 evaluation questions for my MCP server. What makes a good evaluation question? Show me the XML format and give me examples of questions that properly test whether LLMs can use my tools effectively.

output_examples.input: Build an MCP server for a GitHub API integration
output: MCP Server Development Guide: GitHub Integration
- Study GitHub REST API documentation thoroughly
- Identify high-value workflows (not just endpoint wrappers)
- Plan tools around user tasks: search_repos, create_issue, list_prs
- Set up project structure following language guide
- Create shared API client with authentication handling
- Implement tools with Pydantic/Zod input validation
- Verify tool names follow convention: github_search_repos
- Check pagination and character limits are implemented
- Ensure error messages guide the LLM toward correct usage
- Create 10 realistic questions requiring multiple tool calls
- Save as XML file and run: python scripts/evaluation.py -t stdio -c python -a github_server.py evaluation.xml

best_practices: Design tools for complete workflows, not individual API endpoints - consolidate related operations into powerful tools
Use human-readable identifiers and provide concise vs detailed response format options to save context
Implement proper pagination and character limits to prevent overwhelming LLM context windows
anti_patterns: Simply wrapping existing API endpoints as tools - this forces LLMs to make many calls and understand API specifics
Returning exhaustive data dumps instead of high-signal information relevant to the task
Using technical codes or IDs without human-readable labels that help LLMs understand the data

faq.question: What programming languages are supported for MCP servers?
faq.answer: Python with the official MCP Python SDK (FastMCP) and TypeScript with the MCP TypeScript SDK. Both provide similar functionality with language-appropriate patterns.

faq.question: What transport options are available for MCP servers?
faq.answer: Three main options: stdio for local subprocess integration, HTTP for web services, and SSE for real-time updates. Choose based on your deployment needs.

faq.question: How do I test my MCP server works correctly?
faq.answer: Use the included evaluation harness to create test questions. Run python scripts/evaluation.py with your server and an evaluation XML file to measure how well LLMs can use your tools.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using the evaluation script?
faq.answer: The evaluation script calls Anthropic API, so evaluation questions are sent to Anthropic. For sensitive data, create evaluations using only read-only operations or test against mock services.

faq.question: Why are my LLM calls timing out or failing?
faq.answer: MCP servers are long-running processes. When testing locally, run the server in tmux or use the evaluation harness which manages the server lifecycle automatically. Direct execution hangs the main process.

faq.question: How is this different from building REST API clients?
faq.answer: MCP servers expose tools designed for LLM consumption - they must account for limited context, provide actionable errors, and enable complete tasks in few calls rather than many small operations.
